message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's living will should be respected and followed, and the patient should not be intubated based on his wishes. Option A may be appropriate in certain situations, but it is not necessary in this case as the living will is clear. Option B also aligns with the patient's wishes but does not address the wishes of the family. Option D is incorrect as a patient's living will takes precedence over the wishes of next of kin. Therefore, option C is the best course of action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a documented living will that specifies refusal of intubation. This should be respected and followed. Even if the family disagrees, the patient's wishes take precedence over their wishes. Consultation with the ethics committee may be helpful for further guidance and clarification. Option D is incorrect as it goes against the patient's documented wishes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's living will should be honored, and intubation should not be done in any circumstance as specified in the will. Consultation with the ethics committee may not be necessary as the patient's wishes are clear and documented. The patient's family members do not take precedence over his living will.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a documented living will that specifies no intubation in any circumstance. This must be respected as it is the patient's wishes. The option to consult the hospital ethics committee is always available, but in this case, the patient's wishes must be the priority. The patient's prognosis is poor even with intubation, so it would not be appropriate to proceed with intubation against the patient's wishes. Next of kin do not take precedence over a living will in matters of end-of-life care.

We refer to medical ethics for help. The patient's living will should be respected and followed, which specifies that he does not wish to undergo intubation in any circumstance. The patient's next of kin's wishes do not override the patient's documented living will. Therefore, option (C) is the correct course of action. Consulting the hospital ethics committee may also be helpful in understanding the ethical principles involved in this situation, but it does not take precedence over following the patient's documented wishes.
